image.altText: A pile of australian coins on a yellow backdrop.

items.synopsis: Inflation might be softening in some places around the world, but the price of things like groceries remains high.

title.children: Inflation is falling in Australia and New Zealand. Here's how we stack up with the rest of the world

image.altText: A WA Police badge on an officer's shirt shoulder.

items.synopsis: Police say a man is assisting them with enquiries, after the child was picked up in an unknown vehicle while walking to school.

title.children: Man in police custody after 9yo girl allegedly abducted walking to school

image.altText: Older man with glasses and a blading head standing outdoors

items.synopsis: Regional leaders are up in arms following an electoral boundary review set to combine the seats of Moore and North West Central into one electorate, stretching from the Wheatbelt to the Gascoyne.

title.children: 'Ludicrous decision': Regional WA loses seat in parliament to make way for new electorate in Perth's suburbs

image.altText: A sunburnt, man with grey beard stands shirtless on a boat with the Australian flag.

items.synopsis: After 86 days at sea, Rob Barton is believed to be the first person to row non-stop solo and unassisted across the Indian Ocean from Australia to Africa.

title.children: Perth man rows from Australia to Africa to raise funds for youth mental health

image.altText: An underwater photo of a whale tangled in pearling lines

items.synopsis: Rescuers have told of their joy at freeing an 11-metre humpback whale stuck in pearling lines for three days off the WA coast, the second to become entangled near Broome since the weekend.

title.children: Humpback whale freed from pearling lines off Kimberley coast

image.altText: A Philippens supporter holds his nation's flag above his head.

items.synopsis: Action continues on both sides of the Tasman with the Philippines taking on Switzerland after a draw between Canada and Nigeria. Follow the excitement on and off the pitch with the ABC live blog.

title.children: Philippines take on Switzerland in World Cup after Canada and Nigeria draw

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's Ramona Bachmann. It's a goal. She converts the penalty and gives her country a 1-0 lead. She kicked to the left of the goal, Philippines goalkeeper Olivia McDaniel went the other way.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 45': SWITZERLAND SCORE, 1-0

children.content: Ramona Bachmann. It's a goal. She converts the penalty and gives her country a 1-0 lead.
She kicked to the left of the goal, Philippines goalkeeper Olivia McDaniel went the other way.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There was a scrap in the penalty box which the Philippines appeared to have cleared away. Jessika Cowart of the Philippines went for the ball but collected the Swiss number 11 Coumba Sow. The ref says: PENALTY
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 43': PENALTY SWITZERLAND

children.content: There was a scrap in the penalty box which the Philippines appeared to have cleared away.
Jessika Cowart of the Philippines went for the ball but collected the Swiss number 11

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Switzerland should be 1-0 ahead. A beautiful ball was played out to Seraina Piubel on the right. She plays the perfect ball into the box which lands at the feet of striker Ana-Maria Crnogorcevic. Switzerland's most capped player was in front of goal at almost point-blank range, but she gets under the ball and it sails over the crossbar. She will be disappointed in herself. She should have scored.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 37': Switzerland blow a golden chance

children.content: A beautiful ball was played out to
She plays the perfect ball into the box which lands at the feet of striker
Switzerland's most capped player was in front of goal at almost point-blank range, but she gets under the ball and it sails over the crossbar.
She will be disappointed in herself. She should have scored.

image.altText: Three crashed vehicles with police at scene.

items.synopsis: Three people were killed in the crash after an Isuzu, which police say was stolen at knifepoint, was seen chasing and ramming another vehicle onto the wrong side of the highway.

title.children: Triple highway fatality now being treated as a domestic violence homicide investigation

image.altText: Three women look up and point at a tree, while a pathway is covered in excrement. There is an empty pub in the background.

items.synopsis: Business owners call for action as 100 cormorants move into one tree in East Perth, painting the surrounding area white with pungent bird droppings.

title.children: 'I avoid this place': Businesses struggling as foul-smelling bird excrement ruins alfresco area

image.altText: An inland creek pictured from the air

items.synopsis: A multi-million-dollar project to convert one of the world's biggest tides into electricity has met decade-long delays with the federal government.

title.children: 'Stalemate' leaves long-speculated Kimberley tidal power plan dead in the water

image.altText: Happiness

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers releases a long-awaited wellbeing report but admits there are "gaps" in the data and says he is "open to feedback".

title.children: First 'wellbeing budget' finds Australians are living longer but they are less satisfied

image.altText: Two people look.

items.synopsis: When a massive power surge damaged their home's roller door, coffee machine and two air conditioning units, Gunta and Phillip Groves were left with an estimated damage bill of tens of thousands of dollars, without the support of insurance or compensation.

title.children: Couple left tens of thousands of dollars out of pocket after major power surge

image.altText: A white man with light brown hair and wearing a grey 40s suit, stands in a windswept and gloomy desert landscape.

items.synopsis: Christopher Nolan’s masterful movie fuses spectacle and melancholy to tell the true story of J Robert Oppenheimer, who oversaw the creation of the atomic bomb and changed the course of history.

title.children: Why Oppenheimer is the film you should go and see this week

image.altText: A woman looks sad while sitting on an esky on the sidelines.

items.synopsis: Tony Gustavsson says the secrecy surrounding Sam Kerr's injury was partly about tactics, as questions are raised about how long the Matildas star will be out.

title.children: Matildas coach explains secrecy around Kerr injury in 'tough 24 hours' before World Cup opener

image.altText: A soldier stands in the foreground with a missile launcher parked atop a hill, ready to fire.

items.synopsis: Japan's top military officer General Yoshihide Yoshida is in Australia inspecting his country's most advanced anti-ship weapon as part of his country's largest ever participation in Exercise Talisman Sabre.

title.children: Japan's top general inspects anti-ship missile ahead of historic Australian launch

image.altText: Composite image of four people in grayscale layered on top of each other with an Aboriginal flag in the background.

items.synopsis: The Voice is not a new concept — Aboriginal executives across Australia advise people on First Nations' issues every day. They explain how an Indigenous Voice to Parliament could work just as they do.

title.children: This is how the Voice to Parliament would work, according to these Indigenous executives

image.altText: A white labrador sits under a tree next to a lady holding a big lump of truffle

items.synopsis: Truffle producers in WA can't keep up with worldwide demand for the lucrative fungus following an "outstanding" 2023 harvest.

title.children: Bumper harvest in Australia's truffle capital as global demand continues to grow

image.altText: A tiny, fluffy creature with big ears and eyes climbs over a man's hand.

items.synopsis: The western pygmy possum is notoriously difficult to find in the wild, but researchers have found traces of it in WA's Goldfields using a technique they believe could help tackle biodiversity decline.

title.children: How this possum, the size of a human thumb, is helping to pollinate flowers

image.altText: A white woman wearing a green blouse, with shoulder-length blonde hair, looks steadily at the camera.

items.synopsis: Japan's sole custody laws have long been criticised for incentivising child abduction, but the system may be about to change, with Australia playing a key role behind the scenes.

title.children: For four years, Catherine has fought Japan's highest court to be reunited with her children

image.altText: A security surveillance camera is seen near the Microsoft office building in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Beijing-linked hackers access US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns's email account in an espionage operation thought to have compromised at least hundreds of thousands of individual US government emails, the Wall Street Journal and CNN report.

title.children: Chinese hackers breach US ambassador's emails in Microsoft hack, reports say

image.altText: Three views of the birthday cake clock, with the uncleaned original centre.

items.synopsis: A Queensland couple's garden shed clean-out turns up a valuable piece of Victorian history in the form of a birthday cake clock.

title.children: A milk crate of junk almost went to the dump. In it was a historic artefact worth $48k

image.altText: A person holding a Rapid Antigen Test on a blue desk

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: The latest COVID-19 news and case numbers from around the states and territories

image.altText: Raghe Mohammed Abdi smiles a the camera. He wears a school uniform consisting of a maroon jacket and tie, and a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Police said, when they offered to help Mr Abdi — who was walking alongside a busy motorway — he yelled and ran at them with a knife.

title.children: Police opened fire fearing their lives were in danger when man ran at them with a knife, inquest told

image.altText: A young Asian woman with long dark hair poses for a selfie.

items.synopsis: The court heard Joon Seong Tan murdered Melbourne woman Ju 'Kelly' Zhang in a jealous rage, then let her eight-year-old son believe she had left him.

title.children: 'Simply cruel': Judge sentences man who murdered his girlfriend and dumped her body in a wheelie bin

image.altText: Black and white photo from 1902, showing side profile of young woman in her 20s, Victorian era hair and blouse.

items.synopsis: A rare personal copy of Woolf’s first novel with the author's handwritten revisions offers tantalising glimpses into the mind and process of one of the 20th century’s most significant writers. Now the public can access it online.

title.children: Sydney discovery of Virginia Woolf novel with handwritten notes offers glimpse into brilliant mind

image.altText: A Yes23 volunteer hands out shirts in Surry Hills' Prince Alfred Park at the Come Together For Yes rally

items.synopsis: Conjecture appeared on social media this week suggesting Labor MPs were offering 'bribes' in the form of grants to community organisations to become active in campaigning for a Voice.

title.children: Why this screenshot of a Yes campaign email does not equal 'bribes paid by the taxpayer'

image.altText: Close up of Antony Blinken stepping off plane.

items.synopsis: Antony Blinken will be the first Secretary of State to visit Tonga on his trip next week, his third foray into the Pacific in two months as the US steps up engagement in the region to counter China's influence.

title.children: US Secretary of State to visit Pacific for third time in two months

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green kicks the ball during a game with opponents wearing green and white behind her

items.synopsis: Australia's stand-in captain didn't expect to take a penalty, but Steph Catley's maturity reflects a team who navigated their unexpected World Cup opener.

title.children: With an emotional Sam Kerr on the sidelines, the Matildas turned to an unsung hero to get the job done

image.altText: A bald man wearing a bright orange vests laughs with another man wearing a back jumper, they're in a warehouse.

items.synopsis: Australia's buoyant jobs market is so far easily absorbing a record migrant intake, with many employers turning to retirees to fill vacant positions.

title.children: When Diogo was looking for experience, hiring Andrew out of retirement was a 'no brainer'

image.altText: A hand pointing a TV remote towards a TV, which displays the Netflix logo

items.synopsis: Netflix and Tesla suffered significant declines on Wall Street overnight after Blackstone became the first private equity firm to manage $US1 trillion, while the ASX has opened lower. Follow live.

title.children: Netflix and Tesla slide after earnings bump, Blackstone hits $US1 trillion milestone, ASX opens lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Coking coal producer Coronado Global Resources is looking like it will be one of the best performers today to round out the week — and it's all because of what was disclosed in their quarterly report. Coronado's quarterly group saleable production is up 22% compared to its March quarter to 4.5 million tonnes, while its group run of mine (ROM) coal production was 15% higher to 7.2 million tonnes. Its revenue for the June quarter came in at $US728 million ($1 billion), with capital expenditure totalling $US48 million ($70.8 million). Although Coronado has flagged higher capital expenditure for the 2023 financial year, it's also expecting coking coal prices to remain well above the long-term average, and demand to continue to rise. Put that all together, and it makes sense why its share price is tracking up today — it's given investors something to be optimistic about.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coronado is shaping up to be big winner today — here's why

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is staying lower as we move through the trading day, down 0.3% as of 1:30pm AEST to 7,303 points. With only a few hours of trade left, it's looking increasingly likely the local share market will finish roughly where it started this week. A continued slide in tech stocks is a big driver behind the ASX's dip, with the technology sector down 1.1%, and the academic and educational, industrials and financial sectors each down 0.7%. Consumer non-cyclicals are up 1.1% though, while energy has gained 0.6%. As for the top movers: Ingenia Communities +4.1% Coronado Global Resources: +2.8% Endeavour Group +2% Whitehaven Coal +1.95 Treasury Wine +1.8% At the other end, miners are among the worst performers: Mineral Resources -6.9% Lake Resources -5.5% Newcrest Mining -5.2% Syrah Resources -5.1% Imugene -5%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dips as tech stocks continue to slide

local share market will finish roughly where it started

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Cryptocurrency exchange FTX Trading has sued founder Sam Bankman-Fried in an attempt to recoup more than $US1 billion that he and other executives allegedly misappropriated before the company went bankrupt. The complaint filed in Delaware bankruptcy court also names as defendants Caroline Ellison, who led Bankman-Fried's Alameda Research hedge fund; former FTX technology chief Zixiao "Gary" Wang ; and former FTX engineering director Nishad Singh. FTX said the defendants continually misappropriated funds to finance luxury condominiums, political contributions, speculative investments and other "pet projects", while committing "one of the largest financial frauds in history". The alleged fraudulent transfers occurred between February 2020 and November 2022 when FTX filed for Chapter 11 protection, and could be undone — or "avoided" — under the US bankruptcy code or Delaware law, FTX said. A spokesman for Bankman-Fried declined a request for comment from Reuters. Bankman-Friend has pleaded not guilty to several criminal charges, while Ellison, Wang and Singh have pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FTX sues founder Sam Bankman-Fried to recoup $US1 billion

Bankman-Friend has pleaded not guilty to several criminal charges, while Ellison, Wang and Singh have pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors.
